source.6930f94b:
# Importing Seaborn library
import seaborn as sns
#Importing matplotlib libraries 
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
%matplotlib inline
source.3d0f798c:
#importing a data set 
tips = sns.load_dataset('tips')
tips.head()
source.4abe849f:
fig = sns.displot(tips['total_bill'], height= 5, aspect = 2, kde = True, bins = 30)
fig.fig.set_size_inches(15,5)
plt.show()
source.72219f08:
sns.displot(tips['tip'], height= 5, aspect = 2, kde = True, bins = 30)
fig.fig.set_size_inches(15,5)
plt.show()
source.ea5e5c7e:
fig = sns.jointplot(x = tips['total_bill'], y = tips['tip'], data = tips, kind = 'hex')
fig.fig.set_size_inches(15,8)
source.260bbef7:
fig = sns.jointplot(x = "total_bill", y = 'tip', data = tips, kind = 'reg')
fig.fig.set_size_inches(15,8)
source.ced2f2f3:
fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize = (15,5))
sns.rugplot(tips['total_bill'], height = 0.6) # height is height of lines - each data point is a line
ax.set_title("Rugplot", fontsize = 18)
plt.show()
source.9fc74028:
#First declare the fig and ax objects matplot way, subplots here are one with a fig size
fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize = (15,5))
# ax = ax makes the sns plot to be the content of the matplot
sns.kdeplot(tips['total_bill'], ax = ax)
# ax can now have variety of styling options
ax.set_xlabel('Bills in Bin', fontsize=16)
ax.set_title ('KDE Plot', fontsize = 18)
#overlay another plot on this with the same ax 
sns.rugplot(tips['total_bill'], ax = ax, height = 0.5)

plt.show()
source.f632f54d:
fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize = (10,5))
sns.barplot(ax = ax, x = 'sex', y = 'total_bill', data = tips, estimator = sum, )
#estimator here is an aggregator function like, sum, mean, std, or other functions
ax.set_title('Bar Plot Male/Female, their total bill') # Women bills are totalled to low
plt.show()
source.2ac31b27:
fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize = (10,5))
sns.barplot(ax = ax, y = 'sex', x = 'total_bill', data = tips, estimator = sum,orient = 'h')
#estimator here is an aggregator function like, sum, mean, std, or other functions
ax.set_title('Bar Plot Male/Female, their total bill') # Women bills are totalled to low
plt.show()
source.898438db:
#This is basically a categorical Bar plot with counts of the variable as its y value
#There is no need to specify the y in this plot, 
fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize = (10,5))
sns.countplot(ax = ax,x = tips['sex'])
plt.show()
source.4dd2d08c:
#Box plot gives the distrubtion and statistical information of a categorical variable

fig = plt.figure(figsize = (10,5))
sns.boxplot(y = 'tip', x = 'sex', data = tips, orient = 'v', hue = 'time') # hue options gives more granualrity 
plt.show()

# fromt the below plot it is evident Male customers give more tips irrespective if it is lunch time or dinner time
source.d5c16f5d:
fig = plt.figure(figsize = (10,5))
sns.violinplot(y = 'tip', x = 'sex', data = tips, orient = 'v', hue = 'time') # hue options gives more granualrity 
plt.show()
source.3c1bd935:
fig = plt.figure(figsize = (10,5))
sns.violinplot(y = 'tip', x = 'time', data = tips, orient = 'v', hue = 'sex', split = True )# hue options gives more granualrity 
plt.show()
source.de54fec1:
fig = plt.figure(figsize = (10,5))
sns.stripplot(data = tips, x = 'day', y = 'total_bill')
plt.show()
source.58e63f54:

sns.violinplot(data = tips, x = 'day', y = 'total_bill')
sns.swarmplot(data = tips, x = 'day', y = 'total_bill', color = 'black')
plt.show()
source.dd56192b:
fig = plt.figure(figsize = (10,5))
#sns.violinplot(data = tips, x = 'day', y = 'total_bill')
sns.catplot(data = tips, x = 'day', y = 'total_bill', hue = 'sex')
plt.show()
source.ca2efaa3:
# Example for matrix data. Matrix data is different from tabular data. Both, columns are features in the matrix format
# correlation data of numerical features in a data frame is an example of that
df = pd.read_csv("/kaggle/input/iris-dataset/Iris.csv")
df.head()

df_corr = df.drop('Id', axis = 1).corr()
df_corr
source.5dd4fe33:
fig = plt.figure(figsize = (10,5))
sns.heatmap(data = df_corr, annot= True, cmap = 'coolwarm') #Anootation true prints the values in each block
plt.show()
source.919b4929:
#Flights data year wise passengers with month wise as rows - Matrix data 
fp = flights.pivot_table(index = 'month', columns = 'year', values = 'passengers')
fp
source.ee2ff958:
fig = plt.figure(figsize = (15,15))
sns.heatmap(data = fp, cmap = "coolwarm",linecolor = 'black', linewidths = 3, annot = True, fmt='g')
plt.show()
source.68bd7f35:
# Multiple line plots to show that how month wise passengers count, per each year
fig = plt.figure(figsize = (15,5))
sns.lineplot(x = 'month', y = 'passengers', data = flights, hue = 'year')
plt.show()

# July, Aug months each year the passenger count is high ( Season )
source.17eac422:
#pairplot is a grid plot
fig = plt.figure(figsize = (15,10))
sns.pairplot(df.drop('Id', axis = 1))
plt.show()
source.e1e4ab95:
# pair grid 
# this plot type gives us greater flexibiliy of 
g = sns.PairGrid(df.drop('Id', axis = 1))
g.map_diag(sns.histplot)
g.map_upper(plt.scatter)
g.map_lower(sns.kdeplot)
plt.show()
source.8da1acfc:
#fig = plt.figure(figsize = (20,5))
g = sns.FacetGrid(tips, col="time", height = 5)
g.map(sns.histplot, "tip")
g.fig
source.5dff065b:
g = sns.FacetGrid(tips, col="time", row="sex", height = 5)
g.map_dataframe(sns.histplot, x="total_bill", binwidth=2)
g.set_axis_labels("Total bill", "Count")
plt.show()
source.bc1467fb:
# This is basically a scatter plot between two numerical variables showing, if there exist any linearity ( regression ) between them
sns.lmplot(x = 'total_bill', y = 'tip', data = tips, hue = 'sex')
plt.show()
source.402ce468:
sns.lmplot(x = 'total_bill', y = 'tip', data = tips, col = 'sex') # Instaead of hue separation with colour
plt.show()
source.bff3f4a6:
# Height and Aspect ratio of the figure
sns.lmplot(x = 'total_bill', y = 'tip', data = tips, hue = 'sex', aspect= 0.8, height = 5 )
plt.show()
source.f5c20052:

# Height and Aspect ratio of the figure
sns.lmplot(x = 'total_bill', y = 'tip', data = tips, hue = 'sex', aspect= 0.8, height = 5 , palette= "viridis")
plt.show()

sns.set_context("paper", font_scale=1.2)
sns.lmplot(x = 'total_bill', y = 'tip', data = tips, hue = 'sex', palette= "viridis", )
plt.show()
